# Scope: Major cybersecurity events in 2: # Assumptions: Dates are based on public disclosure or event occurrence.

takedowns: malware) are semicolon-separated and enclosed in quotes.

column5: description
column9: potential_impact_on_malware
column13: notes

Dutch police arrest alleged authors of 'CoinVault' ransomware
column5: Dutch police arrested two men suspected of developing the CoinVault and Bitcryptor ransomware. Authorities also obtained the decryption key database._x000D_
Reduces activity of specific ransomware families; provides decryption keys to victims.
column9: Successful law enforcement action that directly led to a decryption tool being made available for victims.

column5: A critical remote code execution vulnerability in Adobe Flash Player was disclosed and actively exploited in the wild. Patched by Adobe in APSB16-10.
column9: Enables initial access and payload delivery via exploit kits (e.g., Magnitude EK).
column13: Flash vulnerabilities were a primary vector for exploit kits delivering ransomware like Cerber and Locky in 2016.

TeslaCrypt operators release master decryption key
column5: The operators of the TeslaCrypt ransomware shut down their operation and publicly released the master decryption key
column6: allowing all victims to recover their files for free.
column9: TeslaCrypt
column10: Effectively ends the threat from this specific ransomware family.
column11: {"notes":"All victims can decrypt files for free."}

column5: The Necurs botnet
column6: the primary distribution engine for Locky ransomware
column7: went offline for several weeks. This caused a massive
column8: immediate drop in Locky spam campaigns.
column9: N/A
column12: Temporarily halts initial access for a major ransomware family.
column13: {"spam_drop_percent":97}

column5: The Shadow Brokers group released their first cache of alleged NSA hacking tools. While the most damaging tools (like EternalBlue) were not in this initial dump
column6: it signaled a new threat of nation-state tools being available to criminals.
column9: N/A
column10: Signaled the future availability of highly effective exploits, which would later be used by ransomware.

Krebs on Security hit by record 620 Gbps DDoS
column5: Brian Krebs's website was targeted by a massive DDoS attack (620 Gbps) launched by the Mirai botnet
column6: forcing it offline. The scale of the attack was unprecedented at the time.
column9: Mirai
column10: Demonstrated the power of IoT botnets and the massive scale of DDoS attacks they could generate.

column5: The source code for the Mirai botnet was publicly released on a hacking forum.
column9: Dramatically lowers the bar for creating new IoT botnets, leading to numerous variants and widespread scanning/attacks.
column13: Directly led to the proliferation of Mirai variants and the subsequent Dyn DDoS attack.

column5: The Mirai botnet was used to launch a 1.2 Tbps DDoS attack against DNS provider Dyn
column6: causing widespread outages for major websites in North America and Europe
column9: and Reddit.
column13: Demonstrated the systemic risk of insecure IoT devices to core internet infrastructure.

column5: A critical privilege escalation vulnerability in the Linux kernel was disclosed. It allowed a local user to gain root privileges.
column9: Provides a mechanism for malware on a compromised Linux host (e.g., a web server) to gain full administrative rights.
column13: A fundamental Linux vulnerability that existed for many years, impacting a vast number of servers and devices (including Android).

column5: A global law enforcement operation dismantled the 'Avalanche' botnet infrastructure
column6: which was a delivery platform for numerous malware families
column9: N/A
column11: Disrupts the C2 and delivery infrastructure for a wide range of malware families.
column13: https://www.europol.europa.eu/media-press/newsroom-press-releases/avalanche-network-dismantled-in-international-cyber-operation

column5: WikiLeaks began publishing 'Vault 7'
column6: a series of documents detailing CIA hacking tools and capabilities. This included exploits for iOS
column9: N/A
column12: Revealed numerous zero-day vulnerabilities and nation-state cyber capabilities, increasing awareness and risk.
column13: {"notes":"Revealed CIA hacking tools."}

column5: Microsoft released security bulletin MS17-010
column6: which patched multiple critical vulnerabilities in the Windows SMBv1 server. This patch was critical in stopping WannaCry
column7: but many organizations failed to apply it.
column11: Provides the primary mitigation for the EternalBlue exploit, which fueled the largest ransomware outbreaks of the year.
column13: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/security-updates/securitybulletins/2017/ms17-010

column5: The Shadow Brokers group leaked the 'EternalBlue' (MS17-010) and 'EternalRomance' exploits
column6: alleged to be NSA tools. These exploits allowed for remote code execution over SMBv1.
column9: WannaCry; NotPetya; Bad Rabbit
column10: Dramatically enables wormable malware, allowing ransomware to spread automatically and rapidly across networks without user interaction.

column5: A remote code execution vulnerability in Microsoft Office/WordPad was disclosed. It allowed code execution when a user opened a specially crafted document (e.g.
column9: NotPetya
column10: Enables initial access via phishing documents. Was used as one of the infection vectors for NotPetya.

This vulnerability was exploited by various malware, including as a secondary vector in the NotPetya attacks.

column5: A massive global ransomware attack using the EternalBlue exploit (MS17-010) to spread as a worm. It crippled organizations worldwide
column6: most notably the UK's National Health Service (NHS).
column9: WannaCry
column10: Demonstrated the catastrophic impact of combining ransomware with a wormable nation-state exploit.

The first major global wormable ransomware event.

column5: A destructive wiper attack disguised as ransomware
column6: primarily targeting Ukraine via a compromised update to M.E.Doc software. It used EternalBlue and other methods for lateral movement
column11: Demonstrated the use of a supply-chain attack to deploy a wiper with devastating financial and operational impact.

Widely considered the most financially damaging cyberattack in history.

column5: A coordinated international law enforcement operation seized and shut down two of the largest dark web marketplaces
column9: N/A
column10: Disrupts the ecosystem for selling malware, stolen data, and other cybercrime tools.

This operation disrupted a key hub for cybercriminal activity, including RaaS offerings.

column5: Equifax announced a massive data breach affecting 147 million people. The breach occurred from May-July 2017 by exploiting a vulnerability in Apache Struts (CVE-2017-5638).
column9: Massive loss of sensitive PII (SSNs, birth dates), providing raw material for identity theft and sophisticated phishing for years to come.

One of the most significant PII breaches in history, caused by failure to patch a known vulnerability.

column5: A critical remote code execution vulnerability in Apache Struts 2 was disclosed. It was easy to exploit and allowed attackers to take full control of a web server.
column9: Enables initial access to unpatched web servers, leading to data breaches (Equifax) and potential malware deployment.

The vulnerability responsible for the Equifax breach. It was patched, but Equifax failed to apply the patch.

column5: A remote code execution vulnerability in Huawei HG532 routers was disclosed. It was quickly exploited by a variant of the Mirai botnet (Satori).
column9: Provides a new vector for IoT botnets to compromise routers and add them to their network.

Showed the continued evolution of IoT botnets actively incorporating new exploits.

column5: Public disclosure of Meltdown (CVE-2017-5754) and Spectre (CVE-2017-5753
column7: a class of side-channel vulnerabilities affecting nearly all modern CPUs.
column9: AMD
column13: Fundamental vulnerability in hardware, potentially allowing malware to bypass memory isolation and steal sensitive data (passwords, keys) from other processes.

A landmark event in hardware security, requiring massive patching efforts at the OS and firmware levels.
City of Atlanta hit by SamSam Ransomware
column5: The City of Atlanta's municipal services were crippled by a targeted SamSam ransomware attack
column6: disrupting services for days and costing millions in recovery.
column9: SamSam
column10: Highlighted the vulnerability of municipal governments to targeted ransomware and the high recovery costs.

One of the most high-profile ransomware attacks on a US city, demonstrating the impact of 'big game hunting'.

column5: The FBI seized a key C2 domain (toknowall.com) used by the VPNFilter botnet and publicly advised all SOHO router owners to reboot their devices to disrupt the malware.
column9: Disrupted a large, state-sponsored botnet and mitigated the immediate threat of its destructive payload.

LockerGoga ransomware attack hits Norsk Hydro
column5: Norwegian aluminium producer Norsk Hydro suffered a major cyber-attack that forced it to shut down operations across its global organisation. Investigations linked the attack to LockerGoga ransomware.
column9: Demonstrated destructive potential of manual ransomware in industrial environments.
column13: Hydro publicly communicated the attack and refused to pay ransom.

column5: Microsoft issued a critical patch for the remote desktop vulnerability known as BlueKeep. The wormable bug (CVE-2019-0708) could allow remote code execution on unpatched Windows systems.
column9: Unpatched systems provided potential entry points for ransomware operators until widely patched.
column13: BlueKeep exploitation was later observed in the wild in November 2019.

column5: Attackers began exploiting a deserialization flaw in Oracle WebLogic (CVE-2019-2725) to deploy the new ransomware Sodinokibi/REvil. Oracle released a patch on April 26.
column9: Enabled initial access for REvil campaigns and signaled rise of aggressive RaaS.
column13: The vulnerability allowed unauthenticated remote code execution in WebLogic.

column5: A coordinated ransomware attack affected more than 20 small local government entities in Texas. The state activated its operations center and by August 23 had moved victims into recovery; no ransom was paid.
column9: Highlighted vulnerabilities in municipal networks and spurred guidance on incident response and recovery.
column13: The incident underscored the importance of preparedness in smaller government agencies.

Emotet botnet reactivates after three‑month hiatus
column5: Check Point researchers observed the Emotet botnet resume activity in August 2019 after being dormant since June. The botnet renewed spam campaigns with malicious Word documents delivering Emotet.
column9: Reactivation boosted distribution of TrickBot and Ryuk, fueling subsequent ransomware incidents.
column13: Emotet returned as the fifth most prevalent malware in September 2019.

Snatch ransomware observed rebooting Windows into Safe Mode
column5: Sophos researchers discovered Snatch ransomware employing a novel technique: it forces Windows into Safe Mode to bypass security software before encrypting files.
column9: Illustrated evolving ransomware evasion tactics, prompting vendors to update detection strategies.
column13: The safe mode technique prevented many endpoint products from loading.

BlueKeep exploitation detected in the wild
column5: By November 2019 security researchers observed active exploitation of the BlueKeep RDP vulnerability (CVE‑2019‑0708). Wormable exploits targeted unpatched systems despite Microsoft’s earlier patch release.
column9: Raised concerns about ransomware worms similar to WannaCry and prompted urgency to patch.
column13: Although exploitation was limited, it demonstrated real-world risk for unpatched systems.

column5: Late in 2019, the Maze ransomware group began threatening to publish stolen data unless victims paid ransom, initiating the double‑extortion model that later became common among ransomware actors.
column9: Introduced a new extortion tactic that increased leverage on victims and inspired other groups (e.g., REvil, Conti).
column13: The double‑extortion model involved stealing data before encryption and threatening publication.

First public report of LockerGoga ransomware
column5: Security researchers discovered and publicly reported LockerGoga ransomware after it disrupted French engineering firm Altran. VirusTotal received the earliest sample on this date.
column9: Marked the emergence of a dangerous manual ransomware that later impacted other industrial firms.
column13: LockerGoga required manual deployment via compromised credentials.

2019 sees the “triple threat” of Emotet, TrickBot and Ryuk
column5: Year‑end reports highlighted that the combination of Emotet as an initial loader, TrickBot for lateral movement, and Ryuk ransomware caused significant harm to organisations in 2019. The synergy allowed attackers to gain persistence, spread across networks and deploy destructive encryption.
column9: Demonstrated how modular malware ecosystems amplify impact; influenced future RaaS collaborations.
column13: The triple threat remained a dominant ransomware delivery chain into 2020.

NetWalker ransomware operators launch affiliate program
column5: In March 2020, the NetWalker gang introduced a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) affiliate model, allowing other attackers to deploy its malware in exchange for a revenue share.
column9: Expanded reach of NetWalker attacks through affiliate-driven distribution.
column13: The RaaS program attracted affiliates and increased attack volume.

FBI identifies Ragnar Locker ransomware active since December 2019
column5: Authorities discovered that the Ragnar Locker group had been attacking organisations since December 2019. The group used RDP brute‑force and the Windows COM vulnerability CVE‑2017‑0213 for privilege escalation.
column9: Showcased new techniques such as executing ransomware inside a VirtualBox VM to evade detection.
column13: The discovery emphasised the need for strong RDP security and VM monitoring.

F5 releases critical patch for BIG-IP CVE‑2020‑5902
column5: F5 disclosed and patched a critical remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2020-5902) in BIG‑IP Traffic Management User Interface. The flaw allowed unauthenticated attackers to execute commands remotely.
column9: Ransomware groups could leverage unpatched BIG-IP devices for initial access; the patch mitigated risk.
column13: Follow-up guidance was released on July 8 due to active exploitation.

Active exploitation of F5 BIG‑IP vulnerability prompts updated guidance
column5: Security researchers observed active exploitation of the BIG‑IP CVE‑2020‑5902 vulnerability. F5 released updated mitigation guidance urging customers to patch or apply workarounds.
column9: Unpatched devices were targeted by ransomware operators and other attackers for lateral movement.
column13: Demonstrated the speed at which critical vulnerabilities are weaponised.

column5: Security researchers identified a new ransomware strain named Avaddon, delivered via phishing emails with a double‑extension JavaScript downloader. It quickly evolved into a RaaS with double extortion.
column9: Illustrated the ongoing proliferation of RaaS models and social engineering tactics.
column13: Avaddon later used the Phorpiex botnet to distribute malicious spam.

column5: Microsoft issued an update addressing a critical Netlogon protocol vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472). The flaw allowed privilege escalation on domain controllers and was later dubbed Zerologon.
column9: Prevented attackers from using the vulnerability to gain domain admin privileges and deploy ransomware.
column13: Administrators were urged to apply the patch immediately to domain controllers.

Public disclosure and exploit of Zerologon vulnerability
column5: Security firm Secura published a technical write-up on the Zerologon vulnerability, and proof-of-concept exploits became public. Attackers quickly exploited the bug to compromise Active Directory domains.
column9: Enabled ransomware groups to rapidly gain domain admin privileges and deploy payloads across networks.
column13: Exploitation increased until further Microsoft phase updates were released.

column5: Egregor ransomware was first observed in September 2020. The group used phishing emails and existing malware like Qbot/IcedID to deliver payloads and engage in double extortion.
column9: Signalled continuation of Maze operations and adoption of data leak threats by affiliates.
column13: Egregor is believed to be a successor to Sekhmet/Maze code.

column5: DarkSide ransomware first surfaced in August 2020. Operators offered a ransomware-as-a-service model and boasted about charitable donations from ransom payments.
column9: Brought professionalisation to ransomware gangs and set the stage for high-profile attacks in 2021.
column13: DarkSide later attacked Colonial Pipeline in 2021.

Microsoft and partners disrupt TrickBot botnet
column5: On 12 October 2020, Microsoft and telecommunications partners launched a coordinated legal and technical action to disrupt the TrickBot botnet, cutting off servers used for command and control.
column9: Temporarily hindered distribution of ransomware via TrickBot and highlighted cooperation between private and government entities.
column13: The disruption targeted command servers and infrastructure to slow malware operations.

FBI issues advisory on DoppelPaymer ransomware targeting critical sectors
column5: In December 2020, the FBI and CISA issued an alert warning that DoppelPaymer ransomware attacks were increasing against healthcare and critical infrastructure. The advisory highlighted the group’s data leak site and high ransom demands.
column9: Raised awareness about an active threat and provided indicators of compromise and mitigation guidance.
column13: The warning emphasised that DoppelPaymer uses Emotet and Dridex as initial access vectors.

Operation Ladybird takes down Emotet botnet
column5: International law enforcement agencies disrupted the Emotet botnet, replacing malware on infected computers with a law enforcement file and severing command-and-control infrastructure.
column9: Significantly reduced the distribution of malware and ransomware delivered via Emotet.
column13: The takedown involved authorities from multiple countries and was one of the largest botnet disruptions.

Microsoft patches Exchange Server ProxyLogon vulnerabilities
column5: Microsoft released security updates fixing four zero-day vulnerabilities (CVE‑2021‑26855, CVE‑2021‑26857, CVE‑2021‑26858, CVE‑2021‑27065) exploited by the HAFNIUM threat actor to attack on-premises Exchange Server. Organisations were urged to patch immediately.
column9: Prevented attackers from leveraging SSRF and arbitrary file write to establish backdoors for ransomware deployment.
column13: These vulnerabilities were widely exploited before patches became available.

Colonial Pipeline ransomware incident causes shutdown
column5: DarkSide ransomware infected Colonial Pipeline’s corporate network, prompting the pipeline operator to proactively shut down operations. The shutdown led to fuel shortages until operations resumed on May 13.
column9: Highlighted the real-world consequences of ransomware on critical infrastructure and prompted policy responses.
column13: The FBI confirmed DarkSide was responsible on May 10; the US government coordinated a response.

JBS Foods hit by ransomware attributed to REvil
column5: Meat processing giant JBS suffered a ransomware attack, leading to temporary shutdown of production facilities. The FBI attributed the attack to the REvil (Sodinokibi) group, and JBS later admitted paying an $11 million ransom.
column9: Demonstrated that even well-resourced companies may pay ransom to avoid disruptions, potentially incentivising further attacks.
column13: JBS stated that no data was compromised and operations were largely restored at time of payment.

Supply-chain ransomware attack through Kaseya VSA
column5: REvil affiliates exploited an authentication bypass (CVE‑2021‑30116) in Kaseya VSA remote management software to distribute ransomware to managed service providers and their clients. Kaseya urged all on-premise customers to shut down servers; a patch was released on July 11.
column9: Illustrated the risk of supply chain attacks and led to calls for stronger software vendor security.
column13: This event affected hundreds of downstream businesses across several countries.

Microsoft issues out-of-band updates for PrintNightmare (CVE‑2021‑34527)
column5: In response to active exploitation of a Windows Print Spooler flaw, Microsoft assigned CVE‑2021‑34527 and released emergency patches on July 6–7. The vulnerability allowed remote code execution and privilege escalation.
column9: Reduced the attack surface for ransomware operators and prevented lateral movement via print spooler service.
column13: Administrators were advised to apply the patch and disable the print spooler when not needed.

column5: The LockBit group released version 2.0 of its ransomware-as-a-service, incorporating a data exfiltration tool (StealBIT) and adopting a double-extortion scheme.
column9: Illustrated the evolution of existing ransomware into more sophisticated RaaS models with built-in data theft.
column13: LockBit 2.0 targeted medium-to-large enterprises with high ransoms and strict affiliate rules.

Joint cybersecurity advisory warns about BlackMatter ransomware
column5: NSA, CISA and FBI released a joint advisory warning organisations about BlackMatter ransomware. The advisory stated BlackMatter was first seen in July 2021 and provided mitigation recommendations.
column9: Raised awareness and encouraged organisations to implement protections against credential compromise and backup destruction.
column13: Advisory emphasised using multi-factor authentication and offline backups.

REvil ransomware gang taken offline in coordinated operation
column5: A multi-country operation hacked REvil’s servers and took over its infrastructure, causing the group’s leak site and payment portal to go offline. The action followed earlier arrests of REvil affiliates.
column9: Disrupted one of the most prolific RaaS providers and signaled increased international cooperation against ransomware.
column13: REvil’s Happy Blog and payment sites disappeared following the takedown.

column5: A zero-day remote code execution vulnerability (CVE‑2021‑44228) in the Apache Log4j2 library was publicly disclosed, allowing attackers to execute code via crafted log messages. The bug affected numerous Java-based applications.
column9: Provided an extremely easy exploitation path for attackers, including ransomware groups, to gain initial access to servers.
column13: Apache released version 2.16.0 to fix the vulnerability; exploitation was observed shortly after disclosure.

column5: LockBit RaaS developers released version 3.0, also known as LockBit Black, featuring improved encryption and triple-extortion tactics.
column9: Increased sophistication of LockBit RaaS and expansion to new affiliates.
column13: LockBit Black replaced version 2.0 with new features and quickly became the most deployed ransomware variant globally in 2022https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-165a#:~:text=In%202022%2C%20LockBit%20was%20the

column5: Researchers reported the voluntary shutdown of the Conti ransomware operation; its members split into smaller groups like Karakurt and BlackByte.
column9: Reorganization of Conti affiliates into other ransomware groups.
column13: Conti disbanded after its reputation was damaged by leaks and geopolitical issues; affiliates formed new groupshttps://thehackernews.com/2022/05/conti-ransomware-gang-shut-down-after.html#:~:text=%EE%A0%82May%2024%2C%202022%EE%A0%84Ravie%20Lakshmanan.

column5: International law enforcement operation dismantled the Russian RSOCKS proxy botnet that had compromised millions of devices.
column9: Reduced availability of proxy botnets for cybercriminals.
column13: The takedown targeted servers across the U.S. and Europe and seized the botnet’s infrastructurehttps://www.justice.gov/usao-sdca/pr/russian-botnet-disrupted-international-cyber-operation#:~:text=SAN%20DIEGO%20%E2%80%93%20The%20U

column5: Microsoft and CISA released guidance to mitigate the Follina zero-day (CVE-2022-30190) affecting MSDT, which allowed remote code execution through malicious Office documents.
column9: Reduced exploitation surface for malware using malicious Office documents.
column13: CISA warned that the Follina vulnerability was being actively exploited and provided workarounds to disable MSDThttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2022/05/31/microsoft-releases-workaround-guidance-msdt-follina-vulnerability#:~:text=May%2031%2C%202022.

column5: FBI, CISA, and MS-ISAC issued an advisory warning that Vice Society ransomware actors were disproportionately targeting the education sector, exploiting PrintNightmare vulnerabilities.
column9: Raised awareness and recommended mitigations for educational institutions.
column13: The advisory highlighted living-off-the-land techniques and exploitation of PrintNightmare to gain initial accesshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa22-249a-0#:~:text=The%20Federal%20Bureau%20of%20Investigation

column5: CISA and FBI released guidance on Maui ransomware targeting healthcare providers, emphasising manual execution and the unknown initial access vector.
column9: Promoted detection and mitigation measures against state-sponsored healthcare attacks.
column13: The guidance explained that Maui ransomware manually encrypts servers used for critical healthcare functionshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa22-187a#:~:text=Technical%20Detailshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa22-187a#:~:text=Maui%20ransomware%20%28

column5: CISA, FBI, and Treasury warned about the Karakurt data extortion group that steals data, threatens auction, and demands ransom without deploying ransomware.
column9: Increased focus on data exfiltration without encryption.
column13: Victims of Karakurt reported ransoms between $25K and $13M; the group gains access via compromised credentials and outdated deviceshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa22-152a#:~:text=have%20not%20reported%20encryption%20of

column5: U.S. law enforcement, in cooperation with international partners, seized multiple DDoS-for-hire ‘booter’ services and charged operators, part of Operation PowerOFF.
column9: Reduced DDoS capability for criminals.
column13: The operation seized domains used to launch millions of DDoS attacks and charged six defendants; it complements the RSOCKS takedownhttps://www.justice.gov/usao-sdca/pr/russian-botnet-disrupted-international-cyber-operation#:~:text=%E2%80%9CThe%20RSOCKS%20botnet%20compromised%20millions

column5: Rapid7 researchers reported a new exploit chain combining CVE-2022-41080 and CVE-2022-41082 (OWASSRF) that bypassed ProxyNotShell mitigations to achieve remote code execution on Exchange servers.
column9: Enabled ransomware actors to gain initial access to vulnerable Exchange servers.
column13: Rapid7 observed exploitation of the OWASSRF chain in December 2022, recommending patching to prevent remote code executionhttps://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2022/12/21/cve-2022-41080-cve-2022-41082-rapid7-observed-exploitation-of-owassrf-in-exchange-for-rce/#:~:text=Beginning%20December%2020%2C%202022%2C%20Rapid7,OWA.

column5: Researchers identified a new IoT malware family, RapperBot, that brute-forced SSH and Telnet credentials to conscript devices into a DDoS botnet and later evolved to cryptojacking.
column9: Expanded botnet threat landscape for DDoS attacks and cryptomining.
column13: Initial campaigns were observed in June 2022, with subsequent activity in August and December; the malware persists by adding SSH keys and later pivoted to cryptomininghttps://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/rapperbot-ddos-botnet-expands-into-cryptojacking#:~:text=FortiGuard%20Labs%20has%20encountered%20new,DDoS%29%20attacks.

column5: The FBI and international partners seized servers and websites used by Hive, captured decryption keys, and provided them to victims, preventing over $130 million in ransom demands.
column9: Disrupted Hive operations and prevented further attacks.
column13: Law enforcement infiltrated Hive since July 2022 and took down its servers and leak sites in January 2023https://www.justice.gov/archives/opa/pr/us-department-justice-disrupts-hive-ransomware-variant#:~:text=Office%20of%20Public%20Affairs.

MOVEit Transfer Zero-Day Exploited by CL0P
column5: Attackers associated with CL0P exploited SQL injection vulnerability CVE-2023-34362 in Progress Software’s MOVEit Transfer to steal data using the LEMURLOOT web shell.
column9: Enabled large-scale data breaches and extortion by CL0P and affiliates.
column13: Starting May 27, 2023, CL0P exploited CVE-2023-34362 in MOVEit Transfer using a web shell to steal datahttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-158a#:~:text=According%20to%20open%20source%20information%2C,MFT%20servers%20in%20early%202023.

Operation Duck Hunt – Qakbot Botnet Disrupted
column5: An international operation redirected Qakbot traffic to FBI-controlled servers and deployed an uninstaller to remove the malware from over 700,000 computers, seizing $8.6 million in cryptocurrency.
column9: Removed a major initial access botnet used by numerous ransomware groups.
column13: The takedown drastically reduced Qakbot-related ransomware operations and freed victims from ongoing infectionshttps://www.justice.gov/usao-cdca/pr/qakbot-malware-disrupted-international-cyber-takedown#:~:text=Qakbot%20Malware%20Infected%20More%20Than

column5: The U.S. Department of Justice announced the disruption of BlackCat/ALPHV, including development of a decryption tool and seizure of several websites used for extortion.
column9: Decreased operations of a prolific RaaS group and aided hundreds of victims.
column13: The FBI’s decryption tool helped over 500 victims and saved roughly $68 million; BlackCat had targeted more than 1,000 victims worldwidehttps://www.justice.gov/archives/opa/pr/justice-department-disrupts-prolific-alphvblackcat-ransomware-variant#:~:text=The%20Justice%20Department%20announced%20today,critical%20infrastructure.

Citrix Bleed (CVE-2023-4966) Disclosed and Added to KEV
column5: Citrix disclosed and patched CVE-2023-4966, a session hijacking vulnerability in NetScaler ADC and Gateway exploited by LockBit affiliates; CISA added it to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog.
column9: Prompted patching to prevent session hijacking and ransomware intrusions.
column13: LockBit affiliates exploited this vulnerability to bypass MFA and hijack sessions as early as August 2023, prompting immediate patchinghttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-325a#:~:text=CVE,T1563%20%28link%20is%20external.

Top Routinely Exploited Vulnerabilities 2023 Report Released
column5: CISA and partners published a list of the top routinely exploited vulnerabilities in 2023, highlighting vulnerabilities in Citrix, Cisco, Fortinet, MOVEit Transfer, Confluence, Log4j, Barracuda Email Security Gateway, and Zoho ManageEngine.
column6: ["Citrix ADC", "Cisco IOS", "Fortinet SSL VPN", "Progress MOVEit", "Atlassian Confluence", "Apache Log4j", "Barracuda ESG", "Zoho ManageEngine"]
column9: Informs defenders about widely exploited vulnerabilities and encourages patching.
column13: The report highlights vulnerabilities exploited by ransomware and state-sponsored actors, including Citrix Bleed and MOVEit Transferhttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-317a#:~:text=Listed%20in%20Table%201%20are,with%20details%20also%20discussed%20below.

column5: Security researchers observed the emergence of the Rhysida ransomware-as-a-service group, which targets organizations worldwide via compromised VPN credentials and Zerologon exploitation.
column9: Adds a new RaaS threat targeting multiple sectors.
column13: Rhysida primarily affects education, healthcare, manufacturing, IT, and government sectors; it leverages stolen VPN credentials and the Zerologon vulnerabilityhttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2023/11/15/cisa-fbi-and-ms-isac-release-advisory-rhysida-ransomware#:~:text=ransomware%20indicators%20of%20compromise%20,as%20recently%20as%20September%202023.

column5: Akira ransomware surfaced in March 2023, conducting double-extortion attacks worldwide, later developing Rust variants and Linux version targeting ESXi servers.
column9: Introduces a new aggressive RaaS with multiplatform capabilities.
column13: Akira affected over 250 organizations by January 2024 and targeted VPN services without MFA, using C++ and Rust payloadshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-109a#:~:text=The%20United%20States%E2%80%99%20Federal%20Bureau,as%20recently%20as%20February%202024https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-109a#:~:text=The%20FBI%20and%20cybersecurity%20researchers,4%20%28link%20is%20external.

column5: Beginning in early 2023, BianLian ransomware operators stopped encrypting files and instead focused exclusively on exfiltrating data and threatening to leak it.
column9: Shows adaptation of ransomware groups to law enforcement pressure and detection by dropping encryption.
column13: The advisory notes that BianLian shifted from encryption-based extortion to data exfiltration-only by January 2023 and warns victims of financial/legal consequences if payments aren't madehttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-136a#:~:text=group

column5: CISA and FBI issued an advisory about Snatch ransomware-as-a-service, urging critical infrastructure organizations to mitigate RDP brute-force attacks and safe mode ransomware execution.
column9: Encourages organizations to implement MFA and secure RDP to prevent Snatch infections.
column13: The advisory describes Snatch's tactics including running in Windows Safe Mode and using RDP brute-force to gain accesshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-263a#:~:text=Snatch%20threat%20actors%20employ%20several

column5: A coordinated operation led by the UK’s NCA and involving multiple countries seized LockBit’s infrastructure, taking down 34 servers and arresting members, disrupting the world’s largest ransomware operation.
column9: Temporarily disrupted LockBit’s operations and reduced its ability to launch attacks.
column13: Operation Cronos compromised LockBit servers, arrested two members, froze crypto assets, and announced charges against developer Dmitry Khoroshevhttps://www.europol.europa.eu/media-press/newsroom/news/law-enforcement-disrupt-worlds-biggest-ransomware-operation#:~:text=This%20international%20sweep%20follows%20a,level%20by%20Europol%20and%20Eurojusthttps://www.justice.gov/archives/opa/pr/us-charges-russian-national-developing-and-operating-lockbit-ransomware#:~:text=The%20U,ransomware%20group%20in%20the%20world.

column5: U.S. authorities unsealed an indictment against alleged LockBit developer Dmitry Khoroshev (LockBitSupp) and announced a $10 million reward for information leading to his arrest.
column9: Increased legal pressure on RaaS operators and deterrence for affiliates.
column13: The indictment reveals that LockBit attacks over 2,500 victims across 120 countries, causing billions in losses and that Khoroshev kept at least $100 million of ransom proceedshttps://www.justice.gov/archives/opa/pr/us-charges-russian-national-developing-and-operating-lockbit-ransomware#:~:text=The%20U,ransomware%20group%20in%20the%20worldhttps://www.justice.gov/archives/opa/pr/us-charges-russian-national-developing-and-operating-lockbit-ransomware#:~:text=administrator%20from%20its%20inception%20in,revenue%2C%20incident%20response%2C%20and%20recovery.

column5: CISA added the critical authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2024-1709 in ConnectWise ScreenConnect to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog and urged immediate updates.
column9: Promotes patching to prevent ransomware groups from abusing the vulnerability.
column13: The vulnerability allows remote attackers to bypass authentication and gain admin access to ScreenConnect servershttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/02/22/cisa-adds-one-known-exploited-connectwise-vulnerability-cve-2024-1709-catalog#:~:text=February%2022%2C%202024https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/cve-2024-1709#:~:text=ConnectWise%20ScreenConnect%2023

Fortinet Releases Patches for FortiOS SSL VPN Vulnerabilities
column5: Fortinet released patches for critical remote code execution vulnerabilities CVE-2024-21762 and CVE-2024-23313 in FortiOS SSL VPN and FortiProxy; CISA warned that CVE-2024-21762 was exploited in the wild.
column9: Reduces opportunity for attackers to exploit critical Fortinet vulnerabilities.
column13: CISA urged organizations to apply patches and noted evidence of active exploitation of CVE-2024-21762https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/02/09/fortinet-releases-security-advisories-fortios#:~:text=Fortinet%20released%20security%20updates%20to

column5: Malicious code was discovered in xz-utils versions 5.6.0 and 5.6.1 that could allow unauthorized access through SSH; CISA issued an urgent warning and recommended downgrading to a safe version.
column9: Highlights risk of supply chain compromises enabling widespread unauthorized access.
column13: CISA recommended downgrading to xz-utils 5.4.6 and hunting for malicious activity after discovering a backdoor in versions 5.6.0/5.6.1https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/03/29/reported-supply-chain-compromise-affecting-xz-utils-data-compression-library-cve-2024-3094#:~:text=March%2029%2C%202024.

column5: CISA, FBI, and NSA issued a StopRansomware advisory on Akira ransomware, detailing its exploitation of VPNs, its multi-variant development, and mitigation steps.
column9: Raises awareness and encourages patching to block Akira’s entry vectors.
column13: The advisory noted that Akira had impacted more than 250 organizations and deployed Rust and Linux variantshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-109a#:~:text=The%20United%20States%E2%80%99%20Federal%20Bureau

column5: CISA and FBI released a StopRansomware advisory on Phobos ransomware, outlining its targeting of municipalities and use of Smokeloader and Cobalt Strike.
column9: Alerts defenders to mitigate phishing and secure RDP to prevent Phobos attacks.
column13: Phobos attacks municipal governments and public services via phishing and exposed RDP ports, using Smokeloader and Cobalt Strikehttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060a#:~:text=Center%20%28MS,74%202%20%28link%20ishttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060a#:~:text=MITRE%20ATT%26CK%C2%AE%20tactics%20and%20techniques,link%20is%20external.

column5: CISA, FBI, and MS-ISAC warned about RansomHub (formerly Cyclops/Knight), detailing its double-extortion model and exploited CVEs, and noting at least 210 victims across critical sectors.
column6: ["Citrix ADC", "FortiOS", "Apache ActiveMQ", "Atlassian Confluence", "F5 BIG-IP", "FortiClient EMS", "Windows SMB"]
column9: Highlights growing threat of a rebranded RaaS attracting affiliates from LockBit and ALPHV.
column13: RansomHub uses a double-extortion model and leverages numerous CVEs; it has impacted at least 210 organizations across critical sectorshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-242a#:~:text=The%20Federal%20Bureau%20of%20Investigation

column5: CISA and partners updated their advisory on Black Basta, noting the group’s exploitation of ConnectWise ScreenConnect CVE-2024-1709 and highlighting new social engineering tactics.
column9: Emphasises the need to update remote management tools and train employees against phishing.
column13: The advisory states that Black Basta has impacted more than 500 organizations and adopted email-bombing and social engineering via Teams to force contacthttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-131a#:~:text=provide%20information%20on%20Black%20Basta%2C

Operation Endgame Neutralizes Initial Access Malware
column5: Law enforcement agencies from multiple countries coordinated to dismantle infrastructure used by initial access malware including Bumblebee, Lactrodectus, Qakbot, HijackLoader, DanaBot, Trickbot, and Warmcookie, taking down ~300 servers and 650 domains and issuing 20 arrest warrants.
column9: Severely disrupted delivery of ransomware by removing key loaders and initial access tools.
column13: Operation Endgame targeted multiple loaders used by ransomware groups, neutralizing malware and seizing infrastructure and cryptocurrencyhttps://eucrim.eu/news/operation-endgame-targets-initial-access-malware/#:~:text=At%20the%20end%20of%20May,Hijackloader%2C%20DanaBot%2C%20Trickbot%2C%20and%20Warmcookie.

column5: An international law enforcement operation seized servers, domains, and about $1 million in cryptocurrency tied to the Royal/BlackSuit ransomware group, disrupting its operations.
column9: Disrupted a prolific ransomware operation and reduced its capacity to extort victims.
column13: The operation involved agencies from eight countries and seized infrastructure used for ransomware deployment and extortionhttps://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/justice-department-announces-coordinated-disruption-actions-against-blacksuit-royal#:~:text=Law%20Enforcement%20Seizes%20Servers%2C%20Domains%2C

column5: CISA issued a StopRansomware advisory on Medusa ransomware (distinct from MedusaLocker), describing its double-extortion tactics, list of exploited CVEs, and mitigation measures.
column9: Highlights the resurgence of a dangerous RaaS variant and encourages organizations to patch vulnerabilities.
column13: The advisory states that Medusa impacted more than 300 victims across numerous sectors and exploits CVE-2024-1709 and CVE-2023-48788https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa25-071a#:~:text=Center%20%28MS

column5: CISA and partners released an updated advisory on Play ransomware describing its exploitation of SimpleHelp vulnerability (CVE-2024-57727) and other CVEs, and noting that the group had affected around 900 entities.
column9: Encourages organizations to patch widely exploited vulnerabilities to prevent Play intrusions.
column13: The update emphasizes that Play exploits new remote management vulnerabilities and remains a major ransomware threat impacting roughly 900 entitieshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-352a#:~:text=Initial%20Accesshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2025/06/04/updated-guidance-play-ransomware#:~:text=Read%20Full%20Advisory%20Text.

column5: CISA issued an updated advisory on Rhysida ransomware, highlighting its continued targeting of education, healthcare, and manufacturing sectors and its use of cloud storage tools like AZCopy for data exfiltration.
column9: Reinforces need for MFA and patching to prevent VPN compromise and Zerologon exploitation.
column13: Rhysida operators continue to exfiltrate data via AZCopy after gaining VPN access using compromised credentials; the advisory covers new sectors impactedhttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-319a#:~:text=December%202024

Scattered Spider / Octo Tempest Update Published
column5: CISA issued an alert about Scattered Spider (Octo Tempest) detailing its sophisticated social-engineering tactics such as IT helpdesk impersonation, SIM swapping, push bombing, and use of remote access tools, as well as its deployment of DragonForce ransomware.
column9: Raises awareness of advanced social-engineering campaigns targeting large companies.
column13: The update warns that Scattered Spider actors impersonate IT staff, perform SIM swaps, and use remote management tools to deploy ransomwarehttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-320a#:~:text=authoring%20organizations%E2%80%94are%20releasing%20this%20joint,as%20recently%20as%20June%202025https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-320a#:~:text=Overview.

column5: CISA released a joint advisory on Interlock ransomware detailing its drive-by download infection method disguised as browser updates, use of the ClickFix trick, virtualization-specific encryption, and double-extortion approach.
column9: Highlights emergence of virtualization-targeting ransomware and stresses need for user awareness against fake browser updates.
column13: The advisory explains that Interlock uses a ClickFix CAPTCHA to trick users, exfiltrates data via Azure Storage tools, and encrypts virtual machines for ransomhttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa25-203a#:~:text=The%20Interlock%20ransomware%20variant%20was,other%20systems%20on%20the%20networkhttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa25-203a#:~:text=FBI%20has%20observed%20Interlock%20actors,2.

column5: Federal prosecutors charged a Missouri man with operating the RapperBot botnet, which infected tens of thousands of IoT devices and launched hundreds of thousands of DDoS attacks; the botnet was neutralized earlier in August.
column9: Reduces availability of a major DDoS-for-hire botnet and deters similar operators.
column13: The indictment notes the botnet targeted victims in over 80 countries and that law enforcement terminated the infrastructure on August 6, 2025https://www.justice.gov/usao-ak/pr/oregon-man-charged-administering-rapper-bot-ddos-hire-botnet#:~:text=ANCHORAGE%2C%20Alaska%20%E2%80%93%20An%20Oregon,attacks%20since%20at%20least%202021.

CISA Adds 2025 CVEs to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog
column5: CISA added five vulnerabilities – CVE-2022-48503, CVE-2025-2746, CVE-2025-2747, CVE-2025-33073, and CVE-2025-61884 – to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog, citing active exploitation and urging remediation by November 10, 2025.
column9: Signals that threat actors are exploiting newly disclosed vulnerabilities, prompting urgent patching.
column13: CISA’s alert states that these CVEs are actively exploited and pose significant risks to federal enterpriseshttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2025/10/20/cisa-adds-five-known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog#:~:text=October%2020%2C%202025.

Microsoft SMB Client Vulnerability CVE-2025-33073 Actively Exploited
column5: CISA and Microsoft warned that a privilege escalation flaw in the Windows SMB client (CVE-2025-33073) was being exploited in the wild, allowing attackers to run arbitrary code and take over systems.
column9: Provides an additional avenue for privilege escalation and ransomware deployment on Windows systems.
column13: Help Net Security summarised CISA’s warning that CVE-2025-33073 allows elevation of privilege and remote command execution; agencies were instructed to remediate by November 10, 2025https://www.helpnetsecurity.com/2025/10/21/cisa-warns-of-windows-smb-flaw-under-active-exploitation-cve-2025-33073/#:~:text=CVE,is%20being%20exploited%20by%20attackershttps://www.helpnetsecurity.com/2025/10/21/cisa-warns-of-windows-smb-flaw-under-active-exploitation-cve-2025-33073/#:~:text=,and%20unveiled%20by%20watchTowr%20researchers.

Maze pioneers double extortion with public leak site
column5: Maze operationalizes data-leak sites and the double-extortion model, increasing leverage against victims.
column9: Enables post-encryption pressure via public data leaks; drives higher payouts
column13: 2019-2020 campaigns popularized data-leak extortion

Mirai variants drive large-scale IoT DDoS
column5: Proliferation of Mirai strains leveraging insecure ARM IoT devices for DDoS and proxy resale.
column9: Enables massive DDoS capacity and commoditized proxy networks
column13: Variant activity ongoing through 2019; scale depends on ISP filtering and device hygiene

column5: Affiliate-driven operations expand, focusing on enterprise ransomware with multi-million USD demands.
column9: Accelerates ransomware scale via professionalized affiliate model
column13: Conti emerging from Ryuk; campaigns intensified during 2020

column5: Persistent loader and malspam infrastructure provides initial access, credential theft, and staging for ransomware.
column9: Sustains large-scale initial access and lateral movement for ransomware operations
column13: Acted as a feeder for multiple ransomware families across 2020

DarkSide hits Colonial Pipeline; REvil exploits Kaseya
column5: High-profile critical infrastructure incident (Colonial Pipeline) and supply-chain event (Kaseya) illustrate impact of enterprise ransomware.
column9: Demonstrates severe operational disruption and multi-tenant extortion via supply chains
column13: Colonial Pipeline May 7, 2021; Kaseya July 2021; both drove global response

column5: International action dismantles Emotet’s infrastructure, reducing spam-driven initial access and downstream ransomware.
column9: Temporarily reduces loader availability and downstream infections
column13: Activity later resurfaced in modified forms; takedown had significant short-term impact
